III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
EMPLOYEE RECORDS
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
Two of twenty new employees did not have verification of
high school or GED completion prior to hire.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
Two of twenty new employees did not have at least three
references prior to hire.
1

R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
One of twenty new employees did not have verification
he/she was free from communicable TB prior to
employment.
SHORT-TERM OPEN
R 400.4123 Education.
(2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate education
program in accordance with 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to
380.1853. Each resident of school age shall be enrolled not
later than 5 school days after admission and continuously
thereafter.
Two of four youth were not enrolled in school within 5
school days after admission.
R 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(1) An initial health screening shall be completed for each
resident within 24 hours of admission to a facility.
2

Two of ten youth did not have an initial health screening
within 24 hours of admission.
Treatment - One of six initial health screenings was 20 days
late.
Short-term – One of four initial health screenings was 2
days late.
R 400.4153 Shelter care and detention institutions; preliminary service
plans.
Within 7 calendar days of admission, a plan shall be developed
for each resident. The plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for care.
(b) An assessment of the resident’s immediate and specific
needs.
Four of four preliminary service plans did not include the
reason for care or assessment of the youth’s immediate
and specific needs.
3

resident. The plan shall include all of the following:

IV. CONSULTATION/TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
On 3/4/21, the Chief Administrator for Methodist was asked not to accept new youth into
the short-term shelter program until the program statement and related policies were
approved, and the terms of the license were changed to include short-term care. I
provided technical assistance and consultation regarding required referral information
upon admission, emergency/off hours intake processes, length of stay, discharge and
service plan templates, processes and documentation for internal transfers between
programs and tracking document due dates for licensing compliance.
On 3/24/21 the facility submitted an acceptable shelter program statement, procedures,
service plan templates and a new application. The program was approved by DCWL
and added to the license on 3/24/21.
Methodist informed me they recently contracted with an outside agency for their staff to
come regularly to Methodist’s campus and provide additional recreational and
therapeutic services to the youth. The names of these staff had not been submitted to
Central Office so that Central Office could run their clearances. I asked Methodist’s
Human Resources Manager to submit the names of the contracted employees to
Central Office immediately so appropriate clearances could be run.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There has been considerable effort made to reduce physical restraints at the
facility. Restraints decreased from 329 in 2019/2020 to only 42 in 2020/2021. This
is a reduction of 78%.
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
Methodist Children’s Home submitted two corrective action plans resulting from
DCWL investigations.
7

The first citation involved a staff not consistently utilizing positive intervention strategies
with a resident. The staff received a verbal warning for violating policy, was retrained in
de-escalation techniques and participated in bi-weekly supervision. Compliance was
verified. Details can be found on the CCI Compliance Monitoring spreadsheet.
The second citation involved the agency waiting approximately 12 hours before
conducting a nursing assessment on a youth who alleged he was sexually assaulted by
another youth while truant. DCWL determined the agency should have sought
immediate medical attention for the youth at the time the allegation was made. The
corrective action involved the on-call administrator receiving a verbal warning for failing
to send the youth to the hospital immediately. Supervision was conducted with all on-
call administrators to discuss the incident and policies were reviewed. The Residential
Supervisory Team met to the discuss the incident and protocol for emergency medical
treatment in such instances. Verification of compliance is pending.
V. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules, ISEP requirements and/or MDHHS policies. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on their
regular license.
